criteriaDocumentation.name: Non-text Content
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to make information conveyed by non-text content accessible through the use of a text alternative. Text alternatives are a primary way for making information accessible because they can be rendered through any sensory modality (for example, visual, auditory or tactile) to match the needs of the user.
benefits: Screen reader users can access descriptions of images, charts, and other visual content
Users with cognitive disabilities benefit from text descriptions that explain complex images
Text alternatives can be translated into other languages or presented in different modalities

techniques.title: Providing short text alternative for non-text content that serves the same purpose
Using alt attributes on img elements
Using aria-label to provide labels for objects

epubSpecific: Add alt attributes to all elements in EPUB XHTML content
Use empty alt="" for decorative images
Provide detailed descriptions in aria-describedby or linked descriptions for complex images like charts
Ensure SVG graphics include <title> and <desc> elements
Add alt text to MathML equations or provide text equivalents

examples.title: Image with alt text
examples.description: A photograph of a person has alt text describing who is in the photo and what they are doing.

examples.title: Decorative image
examples.description: A decorative border image has empty alt text (alt="") so it is ignored by assistive technology.

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check for images without alt attributes
Use epubcheck to validate image markup
manual: Open EPUB in a reading system with a screen reader (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver)
Navigate to each image and verify alt text is announced
Check that decorative images are properly marked and skipped
Verify complex images have adequate descriptions

remediationGuidance.explanation: Add descriptive alt text that conveys the meaning and data of the image. For complex images like charts, provide sufficient detail in the alt text or link to a longer description.

commonIssues: Missing alt attributes on images
Generic alt text like 'image' or 'photo'
Decorative images not marked with empty alt text
Complex images (charts, diagrams) lacking adequate descriptions
Alt text duplicating nearby caption text

criteriaDocumentation.name: Info and Relationships
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that information and relationships that are implied by visual or auditory formatting are preserved when the presentation format changes. For example, the presentation format changes when the content is read by a screen reader or when a user style sheet is substituted for the style sheet provided by the author.
benefits: Screen reader users can navigate by headings, lists, and other structural elements
Users can apply custom stylesheets while preserving document structure
Content can be repurposed and reformatted while maintaining meaning

techniques.title: Using semantic elements to mark up structure
Using semantic markup to mark emphasized or special text
Using table markup to present tabular information

epubSpecific: Use proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6) for chapter titles, sections, and subsections
Mark up lists with <ul>, <ol>, and <li> elements rather than styled paragraphs
Use <table>, <th>, <td> for tabular data with proper headers
Apply semantic HTML5 elements like <nav>, <aside>, <figure>
Use <strong> and <em> for emphasis rather than just <b> or <i>
Mark up definitions with <dfn> or definition lists <dl>

examples.title: Heading hierarchy
examples.description: A document uses h1 for the title, h2 for chapter headings, and h3 for sections, allowing screen readers to navigate by heading level.

examples.title: Table with headers
examples.description: A data table uses <th> elements to mark column headers, allowing screen readers to announce context when reading cells.

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check for heading hierarchy violations
Use epubcheck to validate HTML structure
manual: Navigate the EPUB using heading navigation (H key in NVDA/JAWS)
Verify headings are in logical order (no skipped levels)
Check that lists and tables are properly announced
Verify emphasis is conveyed through semantic markup, not just styling

remediationGuidance.before:
Chapter 1: Introduction
Overview
• First point
• Second point
remediationGuidance.explanation: Replace styled divs with proper semantic HTML elements. Use heading elements (h1-h6) for headings and list elements (ul, ol, li) for lists. This allows assistive technology to identify and navigate the structure.

commonIssues: Using styled divs or paragraphs instead of heading elements
Skipping heading levels (e.g., h2 to h4)
Using line breaks and asterisks instead of list markup
Tables missing <th> elements for headers
Using <b> or <i> for semantic emphasis instead of <strong> or <em>

criteriaDocumentation.name: Meaningful Sequence
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to enable a user agent to provide an alternative presentation of content while preserving the reading order needed to understand the meaning. It is important that it be possible to programmatically determine at least one sequence of the content that makes sense.
benefits: Screen reader users hear content in a logical order
Users can navigate sequentially through content in the intended order
Content maintains meaning when CSS is disabled or custom stylesheets are applied

techniques.title: Ordering the content in a meaningful sequence
Making the DOM order match the visual order

epubSpecific: Ensure HTML source order matches logical reading order
Avoid using CSS positioning (absolute, float) that changes reading order
Place sidebars and asides in logical positions in the source
Ensure footnotes appear after their reference in the source
Test reading order by disabling CSS or using reading mode

examples.title: Two-column layout
examples.description: A two-column article has the left column followed by the right column in the HTML source, matching the intended reading order.

examples.title: Form with labels
examples.description: Form labels appear before their inputs in the source code, ensuring screen readers announce labels before the input fields.

automated: Run ACE by DAISY (limited automated detection)
Use browser extensions to visualize tab order
manual: Read the EPUB with a screen reader from start to finish
Verify content is announced in logical order
Disable CSS and verify source order makes sense
Check that sidebars, footnotes, and figures appear in appropriate positions

remediationGuidance.before:
Sidebar content

Main paragraph 1

Main paragraph 2
remediationGuidance.after:
Main paragraph 1

Main paragraph 2

Sidebar content
remediationGuidance.explanation: Arrange HTML elements in the source code to match the intended reading order. Use CSS for visual positioning without disrupting the logical sequence.

commonIssues: CSS floats or positioning that changes reading order
Sidebars appearing before main content in source
Multi-column layouts with incorrect source order
Footnotes appearing before the text they reference
Tab order not matching visual layout

criteriaDocumentation.name: Use of Color
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that all users can access information that is conveyed by color differences, that is, by the use of color where each color has a meaning assigned to it. If the information is conveyed through color differences in an image (or other non-text format), the color may not be seen by users with color deficiencies.
benefits: Users with color blindness can understand content that relies on color
Users with low vision or using monochrome displays can access all information
Content is accessible when printed in black and white

techniques.title: Ensuring that additional visual cues are available when text color differences are used to convey information
Using color and pattern

epubSpecific: Don't use only color to indicate required form fields (add asterisk or text label)
Don't rely on color alone for links (use underline or other visual indicator)
In charts and graphs, use patterns or labels in addition to color
Ensure error messages include text, not just red coloring
Provide textual indicators for color-coded elements

examples.title: Required form fields
examples.description: Required fields are marked with both a red border AND an asterisk (*), not just color alone.

examples.title: Color-coded chart
examples.description: A pie chart uses different colors AND patterns/textures to distinguish sections, with a text legend.

manual: View EPUB in grayscale mode or print preview
Verify all information is still conveyed
Check that links are distinguishable without color
Ensure charts and diagrams use patterns or labels
Verify form validation errors include text

remediationGuidance.before: This field is required
remediationGuidance.after: * Required: This field is required
remediationGuidance.explanation: Add visual indicators beyond color (asterisk, bold text) and programmatic indicators (aria-required) to convey required status.

commonIssues: Links indicated only by color without underline
Required form fields shown only with red asterisks
Color-coded charts without labels or patterns
Error messages conveyed only through red text
Status indicators using only color (red/yellow/green)

criteriaDocumentation.name: Page Titled
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to help users find content and orient themselves within it by ensuring that each Web page has a descriptive title. Titles identify the current location without requiring users to read or interpret page content.
benefits: Screen reader users hear the page title when loading a new page
Users can identify pages when multiple browser tabs are open
Search engines use page titles to index content
Users can bookmark pages with meaningful titles

techniques.title: Providing descriptive titles for Web pages
Providing a title using the title element

epubSpecific: Ensure every XHTML file has a <title> element in the <head>
Use descriptive titles that identify the chapter or section
Include book title or chapter context in page titles
For multi-part chapters, distinguish parts in titles (e.g., 'Chapter 1, Part 2')
Match spine item titles to their content

examples.title: Chapter title
examples.description: An EPUB chapter file has <title>Chapter 3: The Journey Begins - My Book Title</title>

examples.title: Section title
examples.description: A subsection has <title>Introduction - Chapter 1 - My Book Title</title>

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check for missing titles
Use epubcheck to validate title elements
manual: Open each XHTML file and verify it has a <title> element
Check that titles are descriptive and unique
Verify titles help identify the content
Use a screen reader to confirm titles are announced

remediationGuidance.after:
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Chapter 5: The Discovery - Adventures in Science</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
remediationGuidance.explanation: Add a descriptive <title> element to every XHTML file. Include the chapter/section name and optionally the book title for context.

commonIssues: Missing <title> elements in XHTML files
Generic titles like 'Untitled' or 'Chapter'
All pages having identical titles
Titles that don't describe the content
Empty title elements

criteriaDocumentation.name: Language of Page
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: The default human language of each Web page can be programmatically determined.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that content developers provide information in the Web page that user agents need to present text and other linguistic content correctly. Both assistive technologies and conventional user agents can render text more accurately when the language of the Web page is identified.
benefits: Screen readers can load correct pronunciation rules
Visual browsers can display characters and scripts correctly
Braille translators can generate correct output
Search engines can identify language for better indexing

techniques.title: Using language attributes on the html element

epubSpecific: Add lang attribute to <html> element in every XHTML file
Use valid BCP 47 language codes (e.g., 'en', 'en-US', 'fr', 'es')
Set xml:lang as well for XHTML compatibility
Declare language in OPF metadata using dc:language
For multi-language EPUBs, set appropriate lang on each file

examples.title: English EPUB
examples.description: An English book has <html lang="en" xml:lang="en"> in all XHTML files

examples.title: French EPUB
examples.description: A French book uses <html lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check for missing lang attributes
Use epubcheck to validate language declarations
manual: Check each XHTML file has lang and xml:lang on <html> element
Verify language code is correct for the content
Test with screen reader to ensure correct pronunciation
Check OPF metadata includes dc:language

remediationGuidance.explanation: Add both lang and xml:lang attributes to the <html> element with the appropriate language code. Use 'en' for English, 'fr' for French, 'es' for Spanish, etc.

commonIssues: Missing lang attribute on <html> element
Incorrect language code for content
Missing xml:lang attribute in XHTML
Language not declared in OPF metadata
Multi-language content without per-file language declaration

criteriaDocumentation.name: Parsing
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that user agents, including assistive technologies, can accurately interpret and parse content. If the content cannot be parsed into a data structure, then different user agents may present it differently or be completely unable to parse it.
benefits: Assistive technologies can reliably parse and process content
Content works consistently across different reading systems
Reduces rendering errors and unexpected behavior
Ensures compatibility with current and future technologies

techniques.title: Validating Web pages
Fully conforming to specifications
Ensuring that opening and closing tags are used according to specification
Ensuring that id attributes are unique on a Web page
Ensuring that elements do not contain duplicate attributes

epubSpecific: Validate all XHTML files with epubcheck
Ensure all elements have closing tags
Properly nest elements (no overlapping tags)
Use unique id attributes across each XHTML file
Avoid duplicate attributes on elements
Follow XHTML syntax (lowercase tags, quoted attributes)

examples.title: Valid XHTML
examples.description:
All tags are properly closed and nested:

Text

examples.title: Unique IDs
examples.description:
Each id attribute value appears only once in the file:
...

automated: Run epubcheck on the entire EPUB
Use ACE by DAISY which includes parsing validation
Validate individual XHTML files with W3C validator
manual: Review epubcheck output for parsing errors
Check for unclosed tags in source code
Verify id attributes are unique
Ensure elements are properly nested

remediationGuidance.before: Text bold
remediationGuidance.after: Text bold
remediationGuidance.explanation: Fix all parsing errors: properly nest tags (strong inside p), remove duplicate attributes, close void elements with />, ensure all tags are closed in the correct order.

commonIssues: Unclosed or improperly nested tags
Duplicate id attributes
Duplicate attributes on same element
Void elements not self-closed in XHTML
Malformed attribute syntax
Invalid XML/XHTML structure

criteriaDocumentation.name: Name, Role, Value
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: For all user interface components, the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set; and notification of changes to these items is available to user agents, including assistive technologies.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that Assistive Technologies (AT) can gather information about, activate (or set) and keep up to date on the status of user interface controls in the content.
benefits: Screen reader users can identify and interact with form controls
Users understand the purpose and state of interactive elements
Assistive technologies can programmatically determine control properties
Changes in state are announced to users

techniques.title: Using markup features to expose the name and role
Using HTML form controls and links
Using aria-label to provide an invisible label
Using aria-labelledby to name regions and landmarks

epubSpecific: Use native HTML form controls (<input>, <button>, <select>) when possible
Associate labels with form controls using <label> or aria-label
Use aria-required for required fields
Use aria-invalid for fields with errors
For custom controls, use appropriate ARIA roles and properties
Ensure interactive elements are keyboard accessible

examples.title: Labeled input
examples.description: <label for="name">Name:</label> <input id="name" type="text" />

examples.title: Required field
examples.description: <input type="text" aria-required="true" aria-label="Email address" />

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check for unlabeled form controls
Use axe DevTools to check ARIA implementation
manual: Navigate to form controls with screen reader
Verify each control announces its name/label
Check required fields are identified
Verify error states are announced
Test custom widgets with ARIA

remediationGuidance.explanation: Associate the label with the input using for/id attributes. Add aria-required to programmatically convey the required state to assistive technologies.

commonIssues: Form inputs without associated labels
Custom widgets without ARIA roles
Required fields not marked with aria-required
Error states not conveyed programmatically
Interactive elements not keyboard accessible
Dynamic content changes not announced

criteriaDocumentation.name: Contrast (Minimum)
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large text (at least 3:1), incidental text, and logotypes.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to provide enough contrast between text and its background so that it can be read by people with moderately low vision (who do not use contrast-enhancing assistive technology).
benefits: Users with low vision can read text more easily
Users with color deficiencies benefit from adequate contrast
Content is readable in bright environments or on low-quality displays
Older users with age-related vision decline can read content

techniques.title: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 exists between text and background
Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 exists between text and background for large text

epubSpecific: Ensure body text has 4.5:1 contrast ratio against background
Large text (18pt+ or 14pt+ bold) needs 3:1 minimum
Check contrast in CSS stylesheets for text colors
Test common background/text combinations
Avoid low-contrast design themes
Consider dark mode alternatives with adequate contrast

examples.title: Black on white
examples.description: Black text (#000000) on white background (#FFFFFF) has 21:1 contrast ratio (excellent)

examples.title: Dark gray on white
examples.description: Dark gray (#595959) on white has 7:1 contrast ratio (passes for normal text)

automated: Run ACE by DAISY to check contrast ratios
manual: Use WebAIM Contrast Checker to test color combinations
Identify all text color and background color pairs in CSS
Test each combination for 4.5:1 (normal text) or 3:1 (large text)
Check images of text for contrast
Test in different reading modes (day/night)

remediationGuidance.explanation: Darken the text color from light gray (#888) to darker gray (#595959) to achieve at least 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal-sized body text.

commonIssues: Light gray text on white background
Low contrast in custom color schemes
Insufficient contrast in dark mode themes
Links without sufficient contrast
Placeholder text with poor contrast
Text over background images with inadequate contrast

criteriaDocumentation.name: Resize Text
criteriaDocumentation.shortDescription: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.
criteriaDocumentation.intent: The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that visually rendered text, including text-based controls can be scaled successfully so that it can be read directly by people with mild visual disabilities, without requiring the use of assistive technology such as a screen magnifier.
benefits: Users with low vision can enlarge text to a comfortable reading size
Text remains readable and functional when zoomed
Content doesn't become truncated or overlapped when enlarged
Users don't need additional assistive technology to read content

techniques.title: Ensuring that there is no loss of content or functionality when the text resizes
Specifying the size of text containers using em units

epubSpecific: Use relative font sizes (em, rem, %) instead of fixed px values
Allow reading systems to override font sizes
Don't use fixed-width containers that truncate text when enlarged
Test EPUB at 200% zoom in various reading systems
Avoid using images of text that can't be resized
Ensure text reflows when user changes font size settings

examples.title: Relative font sizing
examples.description: CSS uses em or rem units: body { font-size: 1rem; } h1 { font-size: 2em; }

examples.title: Reflowable text
examples.description: EPUB allows text to reflow when user increases font size in reading system settings

manual: Open EPUB in reading system (Apple Books, Thorium, etc.)
Increase font size to largest setting (typically 200%+)
Verify all text is still visible and readable
Check that no content is cut off or overlapping
Ensure functionality remains intact (buttons, links work)
Test in multiple reading systems

remediationGuidance.explanation: Use relative units (rem, em, %) for font sizes so text can scale. Use responsive container sizing (max-width, min-height) instead of fixed dimensions to prevent text overflow when zoomed.

commonIssues: Fixed pixel font sizes that don't scale with user settings
Fixed-width containers causing text overflow when enlarged
Text in images that can't be resized
Absolute positioning causing overlapping text when zoomed
Horizontal scrolling required at 200% zoom
Content cut off or hidden when text is enlarged
